Award.AwardTitle: Away from Independence: geometrically, algebraically, and physically motivated random matrix ensembles
Award.AbstractNarration:
On the face of it, a matrix is just a box of numbers. But the encoding of information in the form of matrices is one of the most powerful ideas of modern mathematics; the language of matrices underpins nearly every area of pure and applied mathematics, and anchors the frameworks of physics, engineering, and other sciences. The study of randomly generated matrices is one of the most exciting areas of mathematics today, with theoretical advances giving us an ever-growing picture of what "typical" matrices are like, and providing us with important applications in areas like image compression and the analysis of the Big Data that surrounds us. In this project, the PI will continue her research program investigating the behavior of very large random matrices, and how that behavior depends on the way they are generated; this will advance the theory, which will help better understand the applications to some of the areas mentioned above. She will also complete her monograph "The Random Matrix Theory of the Compact Classical Groups", which gives an overview of what has been learned about randomly generated matrices with a particular relationship to high-dimensional geometry; this activity will disseminate difficult technical knowledge about random matrices to a broad audience. The PI is active in teaching at all levels, and particularly in mentoring and encouraging girls and young women interested in mathematical careers; those training and outreach activities will have great impact on the diversity of those entering STEM fields.

The monograph mentioned above will describe the remarkable advances in the theory of Haar-distributed random matrices in recent years. Topics will include central limit theorems for the entries of principal sub-matrices and for general lower-dimensional projections, quantitative limit results for the empirical spectral measures, self-similarity patterns within the eigenvalue distributions, concentration of measure with geometric applications, including new proofs of the Johnson-Lindenstrauss lemma and Dvoretzky's theorem, and results on the distribution of the characteristic polynomial, with connections to the Riemann zeta function. New research projects include the study of random matrices whose distributions are invariant under rotations in matrix space, continued work on quantitative approximations of empirical spectral measures for various classes of random matrices, and in various metrics, and problems in random topology connected with topological data analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Random matrix theory is an enormous field, which has seen extraordinary development in recent decades.  New applications have been discovered, ranging from the more classical settings of mathematical physics into computer science, medical imaging, and quantum information theory.  The common thread throughout this project has been to apply what has been learned in more classical random matrix theory and in other areas of pure mathematics to the study of a wider variety of random matrix ensembles which arise in applications, but which are less amenable to classical tools.  

One of the main activities during the grant period was the writing and publication of the PI's monograph The Random Matrix Theory of the Classical Compact Groups, published in the series Cambridge Tracts in Mathematics by Cambridge University Press.  This book provides a comprehensive overview of foundational results and recent progress in the study of random matrices from the classical compact groups, drawing on the subject's deep connections to geometry, analysis, algebra, physics, and statistics.  The book includes results on the joint distributions of the entries; an extensive treatment of eigenvalue distributions, including the Weyl integration formula, moment formulae, and limit theorems and large deviations for the spectral measures; concentration of measure with applications both within random matrix theory and in high dimensional geometry; and results on characteristic polynomials with connections to the Riemann zeta function. 

Other significant activities during the grant period involve studying the eigenvalues of large but finite random matrices in a variety of contexts, including in particular the eigenvalues of unitary Brownian motion (joint with Tai Melcher), the eigenvalues of truncations of random unitary matrices (joint with PhD student Kathryn Stewart), random matrix models arising in the context of quantum mechanics, modeling random quantum states (joint with Mark Meckes), and random matrices whose distributions are invariant under rotations in matrix space (also joint with Mark Meckes).  

Over the course of the project, the PI was active in mentoring students, including PhD student Kathryn Stewart, with whom she wrote two joint papers; Stewart also wrote a long single-author paper on the entries of truncations of random orthogonal matrices.  In addition to other student projects, the PI mentored the MS thesis research of David Judkovich, whose results on modern versions of classical problems in combinatorial probability have improved on those in the literature and are currently under review.

During the project, the PI and her student Kathryn Stewart were involved in the program MathCorps Cleveland, a summer math camp for Cleveland middle school students.  The PI gave several guest lectures, and Stewart taught a multi-week course introducing basic ideas of group theory.  The PI has also continued to be involved in efforts to support and encourage women in mathematics, in particular speaking in MSRI's Connections for Women prior to the program on geometry and probability in high dimensions.
